title: Mizzou Plant Science Symposium
text: For the University of Missouri‚Äôs Plant Science Symposium, I presented with my colleague Madison Mitchell over her project focusing on flood tolerant maize genotypes. For this project, I focused on looking into lodging data from each of the plots to identify which plots experienced the most and least amount of lodging during the season. We found that lodging data was less correlated with specific genotypes, and theorized that the topography of the field was a major factor on plants that experienced lodging versus those that didn‚Äôt. This was my first presentation experience, and I highly appreciate Madison for letting me assist in her project!

title: Capstone Progress Report - October 2024
text: My capstone project originally started with me utilizing fieldimageR in order to process orthomosaics. But, fieldimageR utilizes rgdal as a package dependency, which was retired October of 2023. The retirement hadn‚Äôt affected R until late September. After days of research and discussing the problem with fellow coworkers, I decided that the best steps going forward would be to utilizing another program for collecting vegetative indices since there is no current documentation of fieldImageR being updated to no longer be dependent on fieldImageR.

title: Capstone Progress Report - October 2024
text:
QGIS and Python
Going forward, my project is going to utilize primarily python for indice extraction. I have been able to calculate NDVI through QGIS resulting in some very pretty heatmaps, but python is more streamlined than QGIS. My new goals consist of processing all flight dates through python. After this is completed, I can then begin analyzing the data!

title: Retail Floral Management
text: This course is still in progress! Updates to come at a later date :)

title: Wedding Floral Design
text: This was the fourth course I took for my certificate and the final design based course. Over the course of the semester, I was able to partake in projects centered around wedding designs, ranging from hairpieces to arbors and bouquets.

title: Morgan Mathison
text:
Hello! I am Morgan Mathison. I am a Postbaccalaureate researcher at the University of Kansas, where I am currently working in the Natural History Museum‚Äôs department of Paleobotany. I am researching angiosperm evolution and diversification in the Upper Cretaceous! üå±üî¨
Prior to my current position, I earned my BS in Plant Science at the University of Missouri in May of 2025, where I also completed a minor in Biology and a certificate in Retail Floral Management. As an undergrad, I was involved in research and assisted in a USDA lab, where I worked on utilizing drone imaging in plant phenotyping.
This website serves as a collection of my past and current projects, as well as presentations and achievements!

title: Floral Artistry
text:
A large portion of my academic career at the University of Missouri was spent towards completing a certificate in Floral Artistry and Management. I love getting to combine two of my major interests: plant science and art. This section serves as repository of the floral pieces I have completed.

title: Special Occasion Floral Design
text: This was the third floral design course I took at the University of Missouri! It primarily focused on event and sympathy work versus every day designs. I was able to further familiarize myself with the types of techniques and arrangements present in this subcategory of floral design and further expanded upon my skills of the major principles and elements.

title: Digital Agriculture Symposium
text: The Digital Agriculture Symposium was an event held by Mizzou over the summer of 2024 that consisted of two days: a formal symposium complete with talks from other professionals and presentations, and a second field day that consisted of visiting the digital agriculture farm. I was able to present a poster with one of my colleagues, Madison Mitchell. This poster expanded on the project that I had been previously working on with her, and focused on flood responses in maize. We were incredibly lucky to receive 3rd place in the poster competition! The picture above is us with our poster displayed at the field day!

title: Seedmen‚Äôs Association Scholarship
text: I was incredibly lucky to be selected for a scholarship from the Missouri Seedmen‚Äôs Association in the fall of 2024. I am so thankful to the Missouri Seedmen‚Äôs Association for supporting my academic endeavors, and greatly enjoyed getting to converse with members of the association!

title: Mizzou Show Me Research Week 2024
text: I was able to present a poster alongside Madison Mitchell, one of my coworkers for the 2024 spring Show Me Research Week at Mizzou! Madison and I continued to present over her project focusing on using drone imaging to monitor plant responses to flooding. Presenting this poster was a great experience that helped me sharpen my communication skills and prepare for future presentations!

title: Every Day Floral Design
text: After taking an 8 week intro to floral design course, I fell in love with floral artistry and thoroughly enjoyed piecing together my passions for plants and art! I decided to continue with floral design and pursue a certificate in Floral Artistry and Management. Everyday floral design was the second course that I took and focused on common design work, such as bouquets, wreaths, and seasonal designs! This course was also the first time I began working on my concept florist shop: Honey and Hyacinth!

title: Mizzou Undergraduate Research Day 2024
text: In December of 2024, I presented my first poster over my capstone project at Mizzou‚Äôs Fall Undergraduate Research Day! ‚ÄúUtilizing Drone Imaging to Understand Plant Health‚Äù takes drone images my lab and I collected over the summer of 2023 and uses them to understand plant health in two unique environments! While my project is still ongoing, preliminary results have found similar NDVI levels across the fields and have looked into a specific dip in NDVI levels in one field during late July. Future directions focus on incorporating environmental and phenotypic data and more comparisons between both of the environments.

title: Capstone Progress Report - January 2025
text:
What is NDVI?
After running the QGIS grids and orthomosaics through the python script, I ended up with a large collection of vegetative indices extracted for each individual plot of maize for every flight. These .csv files included a wide variety of indices, including GNDVI, SAVI, EVI, and MCARI. My project is focusing on NDVI; Normalized Difference Vegetative Index, a plant health indicator that examines photosynthetic capacity of a plant. The equation utilizes reflectance values of red light (R) and near infrared light (NIR) to record how much red light and near infrared light the plant is absorbing versus reflecting. The graphic I created below is based off of another figure I made for an upcoming publication with Madison Mitchell. Photosynthetically active plants would be utilizing a large amount of red light and not reflecting it, as red light is a major wavelength utilized for photosynthesis. But near infrared light is just at the edge of the absorption spectrum, leading to plants only absorbing some of it. In an unhealthy plant, not as much red light is being absorbed and used in photosynthesis, leading to a large amount of reflection, indicating a decrease in photosynthetic capacity.


Project Goal
My capstone project looks at NDVI values across the growing season of 2023 in two separate fields containing the same genotypes of maize in Columbia, Missouri. The goal is to compare the values between both fields alongside environmental data to better understand the relationship between NDVI and genotype by environment interactions (GxE).


Current Progress
As of current, I have been able to calculate NDVI values for each plot of plants during each flight date. I brought these .csv values into R, and with assistance from Daniel Kick, created a script to assign rows and ranges to the values and make heatmaps for each flight! Below are some of the heatmaps from the Rollins 6 Field.



Acknowledgements
This project has been a challenge, and the consistent support from my PI and fellow lab members have been an amazing help! A special thank you to Worasit Sangjan for Python extraction scripts, Harper Lafond for Pix4D assistance, Daniel Kick for R debugging, and my PI Dr.¬†Washburn for continuous assistance and advising in this project! I cant wait to see this project continue! :)

title: BioGEM Orientation
text:
Hello Lawrence!
This past May, I graduated from Mizzou and am now spending my next year researching at the University of Kansas under the EEB Department.
I‚Äôve been here for a little while now and orientation is just now ending, and soon I‚Äôll be focusing more on research! It‚Äôs been fantastic to meet the other members of my cohort and begin outlining my next research project! Stay tuned for more info in the following months! :)

title: Capstone Progress Report - January 2025
text:
What is NDVI?
After running the QGIS grids and orthomosaics through the python script, I ended up with a large collection of vegetative indices extracted for each individual plot of maize for every flight. These .csv files included a wide variety of indices, including GNDVI, SAVI, EVI, and MCARI. My project is focusing on NDVI; Normalized Difference Vegetative Index, a plant health indicator that examines photosynthetic capacity of a plant. The equation utilizes reflectance values of red light (R) and near infrared light (NIR) to record how much red light and near infrared light the plant is absorbing versus reflecting. The graphic I created below is based off of another figure I made for an upcoming publication with Madison Mitchell. Photosynthetically active plants would be utilizing a large amount of red light and not reflecting it, as red light is a major wavelength utilized for photosynthesis. But near infrared light is just at the edge of the absorption spectrum, leading to plants only absorbing some of it. In an unhealthy plant, not as much red light is being absorbed and used in photosynthesis, leading to a large amount of reflection, indicating a decrease in photosynthetic capacity.


Project Goal
My capstone project looks at NDVI values across the growing season of 2023 in two separate fields containing the same genotypes of maize in Columbia, Missouri. The goal is to compare the values between both fields alongside environmental data to better understand the relationship between NDVI and genotype by environment interactions (GxE).


Current Progress
As of current, I have been able to calculate NDVI values for each plot of plants during each flight date. I brought these .csv values into R, and with assistance from Daniel Kick, created a script to assign rows and ranges to the values and make heatmaps for each flight! Below are some of the heatmaps from the Rollins 6 Field.



Acknowledgements
This project has been a challenge, and the consistent support from my PI and fellow lab members have been an amazing help! A special thank you to Worasit Sangjan for Python extraction scripts, Harper Lafond for Pix4D assistance, Daniel Kick for R debugging, and my PI Dr.¬†Washburn for continuous assistance and advising in this project! I cant wait to see this project continue! :)

title: Capstone Progress Report - October 2024
text: My capstone project originally started with me utilizing fieldimageR in order to process orthomosaics. But, fieldimageR utilizes rgdal as a package dependency, which was retired October of 2023. The retirement hadn‚Äôt affected R until late September. After days of research and discussing the problem with fellow coworkers, I decided that the best steps going forward would be to utilizing another program for collecting vegetative indices since there is no current documentation of fieldImageR being updated to no longer be dependent on rgdal.

title: Postbaccalaureate Research
text:
Currently, I am a post baccalaureate researcher as part of an NSF RaMP Program at the University of Kansas in the Evolution and Ecology Department, specifically within the division of Paleobotany in the lab of Dr.¬†Brian Atkinson. My project consists of describing and taxonomically placing Cretaceous-age fossilized fruit specimens from Antarctica.

title: Show Me Research Week Spring 2025
text: The University of Missouri hosts a research week in the fall and spring semesters, titled ‚ÄúShow Me Research Week.‚Äù For the spring 2025 Show Me Research Week, I presented a poster over my capstone project, discussing the work I had done, and the results we had calculated thus far, specifically highlighting the work I had done in calculating correlations between NDVI (a vegetative indice collected from drone data that quantifies photosynthetic capability) and yield, to determine if there was a relationship between the two. I calculated this in the form of Pearson R tests for each flight date, to determine the best time in the season to calculate yield based off of NDVI. (When in the season the correlation was highest)

title: Maize Genetics Meeting
text: As my project continued, I had the opportunity to attend and present a poster at Maize Genetics Meeting 2025, hosted in St.¬†Louis, Missouri. I presented an updated poster of my capstone project, including work I had done since my last poster the previous semester. Besides presenting a poster, and connecting with and recieving insightful feedback from other researchers focused on maize, I was also able to attend a variety of panels and presentations, where I was able to learn further about the wide array of research questions and studies being conducted with maize as the organism of interest. I am incredibly thankful for the organizing committee for planning and hosting this conference, and appreciated the opportunity to continue to present my research and connect with individuals conducting similar studies.

title: Kansas Innovation Festival
text: After beginning my new position at the University of Kansas, my cohort and I were invited to attend Kansas Innovation Festival, a conference focused on the intersection of biology research and technological advancements. For this conference, I presented a poster over my undergraduate research.

title: Senior Capstone Presentation
text: As part of my senior capstone experience, students are required to summarize their experience (research or internship) in a presentation given to other senior level Plant Science majors, as well as other students, faculty, and staff, who can attend. During April of 2025, I presented my own research project, titled ‚ÄúUtilizing Drone Imaging to Monitor Crop Health in Maize,‚Äù where I discussed my project in the Washburn lab focusing on the relationship between NDVI, plant health, and yield in maize. I was able to showcase the project from start to finish, including the data collection, analysis, and interpretation stages, and concluded with my current findings at the time and shed light on future possibilities for the project.
